title: West Coast blues
text:
West Coast blues is a type of <a href="blues">blues</a> music influenced by <a href="jazz">jazz</a> and <a href="jump%20blues">jump blues</a>, with strong <a href="piano">piano</a>-dominated sounds and jazzy guitar solos, which originated from <a href="Texas%20blues">Texas blues</a> players who relocated to <a href="California">California</a> in the 1940s. West Coast blues also features smooth, honey-toned vocals, frequently crossing into <a href="rhythm%20and%20blues">rhythm and blues</a> territory.
Texas and the West Coast.
The towering figure of West Coast blues may be the guitarist <a href="T-Bone%20Walker">T-Bone Walker</a>, famous for the song "<a href="Call%20It%20Stormy%20Monday%20%28But%20Tuesday%20Is%20Just%20%20as%20Bad%29">Call It Stormy Monday (But Tuesday Is Just as Bad)</a>", a relocated Texan, who made his first recordings in the late 1920s. In the early 1940s, Walker moved to <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, where he recorded many enduring sides for <a href="Capitol%20Records">Capitol</a>, <a href="Black%20%26amp%3B%20White%20Records">Black & White</a>, and <a href="Imperial%20Records">Imperial</a>. Walker was a crucial figure in the electrification and urbanization of the blues, probably doing more to popularize the electric guitar in the form than anyone else. Much of his material had a distinct jazzy jump blues feel, an influence that would characterize much of the most influential blues to emerge from <a href="California">California</a> in the 1940s and 1950s. 
Other Texas bluesmen followed: the pianist and songwriter <a href="Amos%20Milburn">Amos Milburn</a>, the singer <a href="Percy%20Mayfield">Percy Mayfield</a> (who would later become famous for the song "<a href="Hit%20the%20Road%20Jack">Hit the Road Jack</a>"), and <a href="Charles%20Brown%20%28musician%29">Charles Brown</a> moved to Los Angeles. The guitarist <a href="Pee%20Wee%20Crayton">Pee Wee Crayton</a> divided his time between Los Angeles and <a href="San%20Francisco">San Francisco</a>. <a href="Lowell%20Fulson">Lowell Fulson</a>, from Texas by way of <a href="Oklahoma">Oklahoma</a>, moved to <a href="Oakland%2C%20California">Oakland</a>.
